newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: India's ONGC seeks foreign Bombay High EOR partner.
newsitem.headline: India's ONGC seeks foreign Bombay High EOR partner.

text.p: Foreign oil companies may have a chance to share production from India's largest oil and gas producing area, the Bombay High fields, a Ministry of Petroleum and Natural Gas adviser said on Thursday.
"We have gone ahead with proposals for a technical tie-up but we may go ahead with production sharing," said Dr A Bhattacharya, Economic Advisor to the Ministry.

He said India's main state exploration company, the Oil and Natural Gas Corporation has resumed talks with foreign oil companies as potential partners in the enhanced oil recovery (EOR) project for the failing Bombay High fields.
Royal-Dutch major Shell, Chevron Corp of the U.S. and Total SA of France submitted written proposals to ONGC in early September, he said.
Last year, ONGC decided to go ahead with the EOR project on its own after negotiating for a year and a half with Shell, Total, Chevron, Amoco and Arco.
"We found it difficult because of Neelam's decline," said Bhattacharya, referring to one of the larger fields in the Bombay High basin.
"We have given it a try by ouselves, but time is running out ... production is coming down," he said.

Falling production of Bombay High crude prompted ONGC to target crude production for fiscal 1996/1997 at around 29.4 million tonnes compared with actual production in 1995/1996 of 31.9 million tonnes.
Bhattacharya said ONGC's latest move was in line with the government's plan to aim for long-term oil security, but it had been taken by the company independently.
An ONGC spokesman said officials were unavailable to comment.
He said a decision on the choice of partner could be expected by the end of December.
